bibl.title: Commentary on the Dream of Scipio
bibl.author: Macrobius

bibl.title: Astrology (Firmicus)
bibl.author: Julius Firmicus Maternus
bibl.note: Wikipedia: "Julius Firmicus Maternus was a Latin writer and notable astrologer, who received a pagan classical education that made him conversant with Greek; he lived in the reign of Constantine I and his successors. His triple career made him a public advocate, an astrologer and finally a Christian polemicist."

bibl.title: Centiloquium
bibl.author: Ptolemy
bibl.note: Wikipedia: "A collection of one hundred aphorisms about astrology called the Centiloquium, ascribed to Ptolemy, was widely reproduced and commented on by Arabic, Latin and Hebrew scholars, and often bound together in medieval manuscripts after the Tetrabiblos as a kind of summation. It is now believed to be a much later pseudepigraphical composition. The identity and date of the actual author of the work, referred to now as Pseudo-Ptolemy, remains the subject of conjecture."

bibl.title: de Vera Innocentiae
bibl.author: Augustine
bibl.note: I think this is Pseudo Augustinian

bibl.title: Speculum historiale
bibl.author: Vincent of Beauvais
bibl.note: Wikipedia: "The vast tome of the Speculum Naturale (Mirror of Nature), divided into thirty-two books and 3,718 chapters, is a summary of all of the science and natural history known to Western Europe towards the middle of the 13th century, a mosaic of quotations from Latin, Greek, Arabic, and even Hebrew authors, with the sources given. Vincent distinguishes, however, his own remarks."

person.note: So Balak son of Zippor, who was king of Moab at that time Cf. Numbers 22:4
Mathias is mentioned in Acts Chapter 1
Joseph Barsabbas is mentioned in Acts Chapter 1
Acts 5:34 "But a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the law, who was honored by all the people, stood up in the Sanhedrin and ordered that the men be put outside for a little while."
This is the latin name for Ahaz, the father of Hezekiah. See Matthew 1:9
Spell MESSEELLACH by William of Auvergne edited Griet Galle, 2003 - GL http://books.google.com/books?id=A8PpoJAyJ3wC

Not really classical, but wrote commentary on Aristotle: Wikipedia: "Eustratius of Nicaea (Greek: Εὐστράτιος; c. 1050/1060-c. 1120)[1] was Metropolitan bishop of Nicaea in the early 12th century. He wrote commentaries to Aristotle's second book of Analytica and the Ethica Nicomachea."

Wikipedia: "n Greek mythology, the Moirai (Ancient Greek: Μοῖραι, "apportioners", Latinized as Moerae)—often known in English as the Fates—were the white-robed incarnations of destiny (Roman equivalent: Parcae, euphemistically the "sparing ones", or Fata; also analogous to the Germanic Norns). Their number became fixed at three: Clotho (spinner), Lachesis (allotter) and Atropos (unturnable)."

Wikipedia: "n Greek mythology, the Moirai (Ancient Greek: Μοῖραι, "apportioners", Latinized as Moerae)—often known in English as the Fates—were the white-robed incarnations of destiny (Roman equivalent: Parcae, euphemistically the "sparing ones", or Fata; also analogous to the Germanic Norns). Their number became fixed at three: Clotho (spinner), Lachesis (allotter) and Atropos (unturnable)."

Wikipedia: "n Greek mythology, the Moirai (Ancient Greek: Μοῖραι, "apportioners", Latinized as Moerae)—often known in English as the Fates—were the white-robed incarnations of destiny (Roman equivalent: Parcae, euphemistically the "sparing ones", or Fata; also analogous to the Germanic Norns). Their number became fixed at three: Clotho (spinner), Lachesis (allotter) and Atropos (unturnable)."
The person Augustine argued with along with Pelagius (see lectio 98 for example)

Wikipedia: "The Lucidarius, an anonymous medieval book, was the first German language summa,[1] written circa 1190-1195.[2] It was based on different sources, the chief one being the Elucidarium and other texts by Honorius Augustodunensis."

Wikipedia: The Dominican friar Vincent of Beauvais (Vincentius Bellovacensis or Vincentius Burgundus) (c. 1190 – 1264?) wrote the Speculum Maius, the main encyclopedia that was used in the Middle Ages.
Wikipedia: "Bernard Silvestris, also known as Bernardus Silvestris and Bernard Silvester, was a Medieval Platonist philosopher and poet of the 12th century."
Socius -- see principium II for named reference -- probably refers to all references to bachaelor reading from Navarre. See Sullivan - list of people receiving degree in 1397

See principium II for the following phrase: fratrem petrum dominum meum carissimum bachalariumbacalarium
actu legentem in domo beati augusti. See Sullivan - list of people receiving degree in 1397
Lecture on the Sentences probably in 1370-1371 (See Zumkeller p. 51)
